item.title: wordcloud from bib
item.description:
Create a wordcloud from .bib file

using Bibliography, WordCloud

function all_words(bib_file)	
	imported_bib = import_bibtex(bib_file)
	words = ""
	for ref in keys(imported_bib)
		words = string(words, lowercase(imported_bib[ref].title), " ")
	end
	words
end

path = "mybiblio/"
words = all_words(path*"mybib.bib")

stopwords = WordCloud.stopwords_en âˆª ["using", "application"]
cl_words = processtext(words, maxnum = 200, minlength = 4, stopwords = stopwords)

wc = wordcloud(cl_words, 
		mask=shape(box, 500 * 2, 350 * 2, cornerradius=10 * 2), 
		fonts = "menlo", colors = :seaborn_dark) 

generate!(wc)
paint(wc, "wordcloud.png")

item.title: Waterfall
item.description:
Simple Plots.jl receipe for waterfall plots (a la Unknown Pleasures ğŸ˜€). Install using:

pkg> add https://github.com/andferrari/WaterFall.jl

and

using WaterFall
x = [exp(-(n - 1e-2*Ï„^2)^2/Ï„)  for n in 0:300, Ï„ in 40:10:160]
plotfall(x, w=2)

item.title: Discrete Fourier Transform ğŸˆ
item.description:
Fourier transforms of a sine wave using a Pluto.jl notebook:

The interactive notebook can be run on binder, but be patient ğŸ˜´.

begin
  using Plots, PlutoUI

  function DFT_plot(Ï‰â‚€, N)
    f(Ï‰) = abs(sin(N*Ï‰/2)/sin(Ï‰/2))
    Ï‰_DFT = (0:N-1)*2Ï€/N
    plot(Ï‰ -> f(Ï‰ - Ï‰â‚€), 0, 2Ï€, label="Fourier transform", xlabel="Ï‰", w=2)
    plot!(Ï‰_DFT, f.(Ï‰_DFT .- Ï‰â‚€), line = :stem, 
      label="Discrete Fourier Transform", marker = :circle, w=2)
    vline!([Ï‰â‚€], label="Ï‰â‚€ = $(round(Ï‰â‚€, digits=2))", w=3)
    title!("Fourier transforms of x(n)=exp(jÏ‰â‚€n), n=1â€¦$N")
  end
end

begin
  Ï‰â‚€Slider = @bind Ï‰â‚€ Slider(0:1E-2:2Ï€, default = 0.7)
  NSlider = @bind N Slider(4:30, default = 10)

  md"""**Sine parameters**
  
  Ï‰â‚€ $Ï‰â‚€Slider
  
  N $NSlider
  """
end

DFT_plot(Ï‰â‚€, N)

item.title: Conv. rate with Pluto ğŸˆ
item.description:
Convergence rate vs Hessian condition number using a Pluto.jl notebook: 

using Plots, LinearAlgebra, PlutoUI

begin
  f(x) = x[1]^2 + Î³*x[2]^2
  âˆ‡f(x) = [2*x[1], 2*Î³*x[2]]
  opt_step(x, Î”) = - (x[1]*Î”[1] + Î³*x[2]*Î”[2])/(Î”[1]^2 + Î³*Î”[2]^2)

  function grad_desc(; n_itermax = 40, x0 = [10, 1], Ïµ = 1e-1)
    x = zeros(2, n_itermax)
    x[:,1] = x0
    k = 1
    while (norm(âˆ‡f(x[:,k])) > Ïµ) && (k < n_itermax)
        Î” = - âˆ‡f(x[:,k])
        x[:, k+1] = x[:, k] + opt_step(x[:,k], Î”)*Î”
        k += 1
    end
    x, k
  end
end

@bind Î³ Slider(1:0.1:15, default=5)

begin	
x, k_max = grad_desc()
x1_, x2_ = LinRange(-10, 10, 64), LinRange(-10, 10, 64)
contour(x1_, x2_, (x,y)->f([x, y]), xl="xâ‚", yl= "xâ‚‚", rat=:equal, cb=false);
plot!(x[1, 1:k_max], x[2,1:k_max], m=:circle, label="", aspect_ratio=:equal, size=(400,400))
title!("f(x) = xâ‚Â² + $Î³.xâ‚‚Â²,  $(k_max-1) iterations", titlefontsize=10)
end

item.title: Sigmoid fit
item.description:
Inspired by the nice tweet of Constance Crozier, here is the julia code to illustrate the fit of a sigmoid as a function of the number of samples.

using Plots, LsqFit

@. Ïƒ(x, Î¸) = Î¸[1]/(1 + exp(-Î¸[2]*x))

x_plot = range(-6,stop=6,length=128)
y_plot = Ïƒ(x_plot, [1, 1])

n = 32
xdata = range(-6,stop=6,length=n)
ydata = Ïƒ(xdata, [1 1]) + 0.05*randn(n)

anim = @animate for i in 2:n
    Î¸_est = coef(curve_fit(Ïƒ, xdata[1:i], ydata[1:i], [1.0, 1.0]))
    
    plot(x_plot, y_plot, label="True", legend=:bottomright, ylims=(-0.25, 1.25), w=3)
    scatter!(xdata[1:i], ydata[1:i], label="", ms = 5)
    scatter!(xdata[i+1:end], ydata[i+1:end], label="", mc = :lightgray, ms = 5)
    plot!(x_plot, Ïƒ(x_plot, Î¸_est) , label="Estimated", w=2)
    vline!([xdata[i]], label="", w=2)
end
gif(anim, "sigmoid_fit.gif", fps = 10)
